author: E. Domec
title: Two Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2016
content: Being written as a play it was very hard to read and follow

author: anonymous
title: Not up to Harry Potter standards
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content:
Like many, I was really looking forward to this story. I have read the books over and over, and they are among my favorite books ever. I know it is a play, but that did not diminish my excitement by much. It's the lackluster story, not being a play, that does this in. The focus on time turning allows for little plot or character development. The writing has none of the complexity or charm of JK's writing. JK did not write it, and I am very surprised she approved this. If this is really how she wants it to end, then it taints the whole story. I will end this spoiler free section by saying that it is readable, but ultimately very unsatisfying, I recommend buying it cheap if you buy. At least you get more Harry Potter after all these years.

SPOILERS AHEAD

First, the good:

- Scorpius being a nice character is welcome

- Albus being a rebel is also a nice storyline, even if he comes across as one dimensional angsty for much of the story

- The descriptions of past Triwizard Tournaments were funny: some of the best lines in the play

- Was a little interesting seeing how the wizarding world would be with Voldemort in power

- The ending where Albus and Harry saved each other kept up the helping each other and love themes from the books

Now the bad:

- Most of the main characters were ruined! Ron was like Fred and George without their wit and intelligence. Ginny hardly had any personality to speak of. Snape seemed too nice, and Harry too meek.

- Way too much time travel! Multiple revisions of time occur from Albus and Scorpius's actions. It was a small part of the books and really helps make it read like fan fiction and not the 8th story.

- Too many inconsistencies, like with Polyjuice Potion and Delphi, who was Voldemort's daughter.

-  Not enough of Hogwarts life is included

- Cedric would not have become a Death Eater! Maybe he would have gone to a different school, but he was too good for being a Death Eater

- Really no good twists to speak of; Dephi is defeated quickly and Harry and Albus make up

We can only hope Rowling makes a proper book 8 and leaves this as the disappointing fan fiction that is is. She owes it to all the loyal Harry followers. This feels like a cash grab.

author: TheBrightestCrayon
title: Few Redeemable Qualities
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2017
content:
The book comes in good condition. I did not like the actual book, however. I've read fanfiction better than this. I don't want to give away the plot, so I won't. There are very few redeemable qualities about this book; Scorpius' characterization is one of them. If anything, read it to discover one of Harry Potter's worst fears (SPOILER ALERT: It's pigeons).

If you want to read a Harry Potter spin-off, just read fanfiction. The cursed Child isn't really worth it.

author: Zach H.
title: just didn't like the book
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2018
content: Not the company, just didn't like the book.

author: Sara Wilson
title: So disappointed
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content: Had I done my homework I never would have purchased a book written in "play" form. So disappointed

author: Estrella Lopez
title: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child Book Review
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2016
content:
I am confused and am not sure if I am in love with this book as I was the previous seven Harry Potter books. Partnering up with John Tiffany and Jack Thorne was a mistake. I am not alluding to the fact that it is written as a play; on the contrary I rather enjoyed reading it as such. However, J.K. Rowling did not put as much effort into reentering the magical world as any loyal Harry Potter fan would expect. Seriously?! It took only a few hours to read! In comparison with the other Harry Potter books, I would give this a solid ‘D’.
 I rather enjoyed being able to get to know new characters. Albus, Scorpious, and Rose were easy to like. However, I did not expect that so many chief characters would barely have a role. Shouldn’t Ron have been essential in the story? I had to reread the beginning, but as anyone who is a fanatic would know, Harry Potter and the Dealthy Hallows ended with an interesting epilogue of the trio eighteen years later. The Cursed Child begins from that epilogue. But where are the other children of the trio? I’m most certain that Ron and Hermione were supposed to have another child.
 I’m sure other readers are just as confused as I am. By reading other reviews, it seems as if I’m not the only fan who is disappointed with the effort of J.K. Rowling on something she took so long to complete. I’m also sure that we would all have advised her to write this on her own and give us something more than the feeling of reliving Harry’s story through his son’s perspective. Every other book contained its own mystique to it. We expected more.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Disappointed in the format it is written
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2016
content: Disappointed in the format it is written, (screenplay) leaves so much of the details out. That is too bad. Even the plot was so so.. She has done so well with all the other Potter books, this seemed done in haste.. disappointed.

author: K. J. Wendt
title: A play billing with no stage directions...
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2017
content:
I bought this from Walmart. It did not even include stage direction. With that out of the way. This is a play and has room to evolve with other shows. Repo! The Genetic Opera was pretty lousy during it's early days but it turned into a cult epic. I would not bother buying this book. Being an old stage hand. I bought it for technical details which it did not have. The story needs work and I am sure it will get better as it is shown. If you want a good adult Harry Potter play and are in the USA I suggest "A Very Potter Musical"  (a musical with music and lyrics by Darren Criss and A.J. Holmes and a book by Matt Lang, Nick Lang and Brian Holden) It is fan based and on Youtube as of this date.
I keep thinking that this story was the British attempt at trying to be Sirius version of that work. As for the complains about JK making money. Her fan base will always be there to give money to her cause. I suggest saving it and buying a Official Lumos ‘Be the Light’ T-shirt instead. I think the time turner should remain destroyed. there is no way to exclude it from this script.

author: takingadayoff
title: Is There a Charm That Can Make Me Unread It?
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content:
Even allowing for the fact that this is a play and should be viewed rather than read, and that it wasn't written by Rowling, this fails on several levels. First, I should have trusted my first instinct to not read it at all. I don't need to know what happened to the Potter gang after the war was over. It was bound to be a come down after that excitement. I don't think that Rowling should even have included the epilog that showed the heroes nineteen years later. Too much -- leave it to the readers' imaginations.

The Cursed Child reads well enough, it moves along briskly and keeps your interest. But the characters are just wrong. Harry is a bit of a loser now and Ginny is just standing by her man not really adding anything to the story. Hermione has a government job when it was clear that she would have gone into some kind of work facilitating relations between the Wizard and the Muggle worlds. And the alternate Hermione in which she does not marry Ron is straight out of It's a Wonderful Life. Remember when we realize that if Jimmy Stewart's wife never meets him she is doomed to be a lonely librarian? Horrors. Well, without Ron (not even Jimmy Stewart) Hermione is a lonely and bitter Hogwarts functionary. Grab those men while you can girls! Any man...anything's better than being single!

So just like everyone else, the Potter gang grows up to be boring, slightly sad adults. Who needed to learn that? Not me.

author: Pam R. Higginbotham
title: Reads like a play
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2016
content: This story is okay but hard to follow because it is written like a play and I don't like that

author: Brett Birkmeyer
title: Not related
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2016
content: This book was not a good follow up story. I just felt disappointed with how the story progressed and the characters developed.

author: BookLuver
title: It was just okay.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2016
content: It was okay. Just okay. I was disappointed. I expected it to be written like a play, so that was no surprise. I guess I missed the in-depth character development. All the characters were, well, half-written. Some explanation would have been nice. I was greatly disappointed and sold my book as soon as I could.

author: Bri
title: Not what I hoped it would be.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2016
content: As a lifelong Harry Potter fan, I was very excited to read this story. Unfortunately, The Cursed Child somehow cheapened the story I grew up with. The original series played a huge role in my life, with the themes of friendship, teamwork, and love serving as meaningful life lessons in my teen years. The weight of the characters sacrifices, in my mind, deserves better then this cheeky script. The underlying story is a nice 'shout out' to Harry's past and the issue he's having with his son is appropriate, but the delivery itself is almost hyperbolic in a way that pokes fun at the whole thing. Especially poor Ron, whose character has clearly devolved into mere comedic relief. Its not a terrible little side read, but its not for those who were expecting or hoping for more of the powerful story we left behind nearly a decade ago.

author: SRH
title: Not as Good as the Rest
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2016
content: J.K. Rowling is an amazing writer and a wondrous storyteller.  This nonsense is not worthy to bear her name.  It is mediocre fan fiction.  I'm sad that I read it.

author: Anonymous689
title: Defnitely not HP canon
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2019
content: I definitely found it interesting to visit a possible future for the Golden Trio & other Hogwarts alums, but this is NOT part of the story I love so much.  I'm dismayed to see that Amazon includes it in their series of 8 (???) HP e books available for Kindle.

author: GIGI
title: I did not like the format
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: Too superficial. I did not like the format. It didn't have anywhere near enough details to be a good read. Way too fast. Not enough character development. Nothing to hold on to and think about later. Just....Blah.

author: Truther
title: harry potter and the cursed child
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2016

author: Carrie A. Richard
title: I love Harry Potter and read all the books
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2016
content: I love Harry Potter and read all the books, watched the movies multiple times and have been to Harry Potter World - I am a fan.  I did enjoy the story line but HATE the format of the book.  It was a super quick read with none of the elaborate details that the other books had.  I know this is a screenplay and that is why but I really did not like the format I think it really took away from key elements that made the other books so great.

author: Megington
title: Couldn't finish. Really tried, but couldn't do it
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2017
content:
I am definitely the only person out of my group of friends who hated this book. Assuming you read the synopsis, I'll just explain my disgust:

1. I immensly dislike he main character. I've read books where villains and mean/terrible people lead the story, so I enjoy reading about a character with a few flaws or personal struggles. This one was overly pathetic. It figures this would be about a kid who doesn't compare to his dad, the great Harry Potter. Who would? It's Harry freakin Potter! There are 7 epic books about what an amazingly strong and courageous character he is! Even he started off with a few struggles before growing into the champion he was. I don't understand how this is the best plot idea that was established. Why are so many people comparing this kid to his dad? And why isn't this kid ridiculously proud of his dad? He has a sour attitude about wanting to establish a separate identity, but his actions don't reflect his wishes. Instead he just keeps brooding.

2. This could still be part of #1, but it felt to important to mesh in there. I don't like how he made me react as a reader, and I'm so mad that this kid made me think that he needed a time out. I am nobody's mother, so how dare he entice the urge to yell at him for acting so childish and disrespectful to his dad! He has a great life, with a family that loves him, so he should be more appreciative of the things he's taking for granted. This is the first time I have ever sided with a parent in a book. A parent. Now I feel old and wizened over teenaged drama. This kid is a huge jerk.

3. I completely understand that this book was not written by J.K. Rowling. I want to state that I was not expecting a similar writing style, tone of voice or even similar level of creativity. That being said, Harry, Ron and Hermione sounded absolutely nothing like Harry, Ron and Hermione, respectively. I was expecting a little change since they're older, but really, these are characters who have been through a war of chaos, stress and anguish, only to grow old sounding like a group of guest stars on Sesame Street. I enjoyed the play format of the book, but with so much riding on dialogue, I was struggling to accept these as the same characters that J.K. Rowling created.

I think 2 stars is overly generous, but that's because I've probably placed my expectations a little too high to begin with.

author: JJ
title: Truly a Cursed 8th Child
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2016
content:
This is in no way reminiscent of JK Rowling's Harry Potter Series. There, I said it. I'm very let down by this story because I assumed Rowling had actually...read it. I find it difficult to believe she would approve it because it screams fanfiction. I know because I've written plenty of Harry Potter fanfiction. Mine is more true to the heart of Harry Potter than this story is. Yes, an amateur's writing from when they were 15 years old is more palpable than this cursed child of a story.

Time travel. Why? Rowling herself said time travel opened up way too many plot holes which is why she had them destroyed in the first place.

Dues ex Machina. Everywhere! Yes, Rowling was guilty of it as well, but hers usually came from a thread of writing from 4 books before. I mean pearl powder? No. A time Turner watch? NO! Get out of here. Such convenient plot pieces.

You know who they should save instead of Diggory? Freaking Fred Weasley. Remus Lupin. Tonks. Oh and where the hell is little Teddy in this story? And the other Weasleys?

As an avid Potter fan, I was not happy. To say the least.

author: sc girl
title: Angry at first but then it had a good ending
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2017
content:
Ok I admit, I threw it against my bed in frustration and had to leave it on the shelf to come back to later. (It was that bad at first) But after the fourth time in reading it, it started to become more interesting(and bareable).I finally finished reading it all the way through.
  **SPOILERS AHEAD!!!**
When they started using timeturners and started talking about bringing back Cedric Diggory I was so dissapointed! (I thought they could do better than that! This is JKR we're talking about here! Cedric Diggory is one of the lamest characters. Sorry Hufflepuff but it is true.) They do have the kids being the heros if you like that but the parents swoop in at the end and help. The whole thing about Voldemort having a child I thought was crazy but once you get over that fact the person they pick is really cool. I thought that Albus Potter and Scorpius Malfoy(Draco's son) were gay, they hugged all the time but they covered it up with Scorpius liking Rose(Hermione and Ron's daughter) and Albus liking Voldemort's child.(I can't say the name that would be too much of a spoiler alert.) I didn't think it was hard reading it as a play script. It had none of the luster as the past 7. Harry was such a brat and they didn't even explain why Ron owned the Weasly's joke shop instead of George. Scorpius is such a nerd he and Rose would go well together.

author: Amazon Customer
title: So disappointed! Please have redone Rowling
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: Harry Potter and the cursed child was the biggest bust the Harry Potter series has ever seen. It portrayed characters we all know so well and love endlessly as different people. Ron is what basically seems like a replacement Fred. Why does Ron now run Weasley's Wizard Wheezes does he run it with George since Fred died? I guess we'll never know SINCE GEORGE IS NEVER MENTIONED!!! Hermione didn't seem right either she went from a bookish know it all to a sloppy Minister of Magic. I really want to understand that she kept the time turner for good reasons like the book said, but it simply does not seem like a Hermione thing to do. She fully understood the risks of time turners in the third Harry Potter. Why, why, why would she keep it in such a easy to get place, it seemed like it was a poorly done version of the obstacles in the way of getting to the Sorcerer's Stone in the first book. Harry seemed off as well, because you think after the experience of being an outsider in the muggle world and sometimes even at Hogwarts he would understand his son more! He even said that Albus was like him in that way at the end of the book, what took you so long to realize that Harry? This book did have great potential, but that was cut down by bad writing and the story being rushed into one 309 page book. I think this book could have been at least 4 stars had been put into a set up much like the originals. We would have seen more of Albus' struggles if the book only took place in just his first year, imagine seeing Albus go through being teased and bullied by his peers. This would have let us appreciate him more instead of him coming off as a whiney, ungrateful teen. I wanted this book to be amazing because this was going to be a book with a Slytherin main character that was not in any way a villain. This book is not that and Albus was portrayed as a weak boy who blamed all of his issues on his farther. I am disappointed because I really loved the idea of Rowling doing a book about the next generation of Harry Potter characters. It breaks my heart that I'm writing a bad review of a Harry Potter book because I practically worship J.K Rowling. This book came off as a fan fiction by someone who only watched the Harry Potter movies and doesn't know the characters at all. I really think I redo is in order because the standards that the previous 7 books set for Harry Potter and the Cursed Child were not met.

author: Michele in Florida
title: Huge disappointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2016
content: Let me start by saying I am a huge fan of all things Harry Potter, from the book series to the movie series, theme park, etc. I have read each of the books multiple times and find them tremendously entertaining.  I am not sure who actually wrote this screen play but I doubt J.K. Rowling actually had much (if anything) to do with it.  It is written as if the author had very little to no knowledge of the characters or story lines from any of the previous books, or maybe they just saw one of the movies years ago.  The characters do and say things that they would never do in the books, and the dialog is not true to who they are in the books. The plot is confused and pointless at times. It meanders through many subplots, often does not have a foundation in the material from the original book series.  I had to force myself to keep reading this thing. Bottom line- don't waste your time reading this if you are a Potter fan.

author: SC
title: Reads like mediocre fanfiction, or an unfinished draft.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2016
content:
A solid 'eh.' Plot holes here and there, overused tropes, and unlike the seven main series books, this was very... predictable. Even the major plot twist came as more of a disappointment than anything else. Many characters were well out of character, even considering the settings. There were a handful of good moments, and I like Scorpius' characterization overall, but any character that wasn't a main one and hadn't already been featured in the main books (read: fleshed out) came across as very two-dimensional. There were a lot of things that weren't addressed at the end that I had questions about, which left me kind of unsatisfied.

I'm sure it did well in theaters, because it does read like something that would have. That said, I feel like there should have been some effort to put it into a more prosaic format if they wanted to sell it as a book. It would have been a good bit shorter, probably, but that's how I feel about it.

author: Rob M
title: Quality of the story compromised by the medium
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2016
content: I am another Harry Potter fan.  The books are terrific.  The movies - not as great, but definitely fun and I go through the series maybe once a year.  Of course, this is a screenplay, and that's easy to get used to.  It's the story that really doesn't jive here.  The story has to fit inside the confines of a theater production, within that timeline, and has to be easy enough for the audience to follow.  The problem is that the nuance and complexity we appreciate in the Potter universe isn't here.  The characters are thin, the story has holes, and the peril never really escalates.  It does feel more like fanfiction.  Perhaps onstage with good actors, the characters and humor might work better, but the story still doesn't deserve to be Potter canon.

author: K. Knight
title: Curses!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content:
Up until about halfway through this, I HATED it. I hated the plot because it seemed like such a re-hash of the original books. I hated the characters because I didn’t believe they’d act as they are portrayed (Harry Potter not understanding what it’s like to be a lonely child? Hello! He spent a good chunk of his childhood alone on Privet Drive.) I didn’t believe that Harry would be such a terrible father, that Hermoine would be so stupid (really? The location of a hidden object is revealed using riddles that two teenagers can EASILY figure out? They’re not portrayed as super intelligent and Hermoine is the brightest witch of her age!) and I didn’t believe that Draco would have remained completely unchanged after the Battle of Hogwarts.

By the time I got to the end, I was OK with this story. I don’t love it. I don’t even really like it. Draco was a much more believable character (though why the sudden change from the start of the play, I’m not sure). But I still didn’t like the way Harry was portrayed or how simply things were wrapped up…this may have something to do with my dislike of the old ‘time traveler’ plot.

Granted, the story loses something when you’re just reading the lines vs. seeing it in the theater. I’m sure the play itself is a masterpiece…and if this was considered a ‘fan’s view of what MIGHT have happened in the future’ I’d be fine with it. Even a fan’s tribute to the Potter series with Rowling’s blessing would be fine. But for Rowling to say this is the 8th ‘story’ (it’s not a novel. Not even close. If you’re expecting the old Harry Potter magic, you’re going to be disappointed.) is depressing. It’s just not worthy of the rest of the series. I’m going to do my best to forget that this story even happened. Having read this, I’m perfectly fine leaving Harry’s story at “All was well.”

date: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2018
content: Very disappointing.  I finished it only because I too am a Harry Potter fan, so one is  just so desperate for more HP that you even read this to the end (my daughter had told me not to bother reading it). The writing is not good, the characters are not true to themselves and there is WAY too much emotional drivel ...that was probably the worst part.  I didn't mind it being a script, but i could imagine it would be very disappointing seeing it performed.  I'm sorry, but you need all the movie special effects.  Like other reviewers, i have no idea why JK let her name be associated with  this book.  I guess it  was another step in stardom for her, to get HP on the stage. That's the only reason i can think of as this was definitely not to her level of skill. The man tried, i suppose, so marks for effort, but that's it. However, all that said, if you are a HP fan, you will have to read it as you will hope against hope that we are all wrong in our reviews as you're so desperate for more HP.

author: Irene Adler
title: Unfortunately, you can really tell that Rowling didn't write this script.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2016
content: Unfortunately, you can really tell that Rowling didn't write this script.  The only parts of the dialogue that make sense are the ones lifted from the existing Potter books (which I love).  Albus and Scorpius speak to each other more like 18th century poets than 11-14 year old boys.  Harry's characterization was so far from how fans know him to be, he was almost unrecognizable. I was so disappointed with the story, that I could barely finish it.  When asked by a friend to sum it up, I could only come up with "dreadful."  I am very glad that I checked this book out from the library, rather than wasting $15.  (sigh)  Fans will want to cleanse their palettes by going back and re-reading the original stories as soon as possible.

author: Julia
title: Disappointed
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2018
content: The concept of Harry's son struggling with his Dad's reputation is incredibly fascinating to me. Execution wise, it definitely missed the mark. The characters we fell in love with were not here and the storyline really struggled. Everything we loved about the books (all the details, side storylines, really interesting supporting characters, multi dimensional characters) were missing here. A large part of that is a casualty of the play format. I preordered and finished this book within 24 hours of receiving it and felt really disappointed. I felt like the magic of the books was missing.

author: fatherbill
title: un-exciting
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2016
content: was expecting a novel

author: Cat
title: Two Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2017
content: An adequate fanfic.

author: Janet Beeler-Marfisi
title: Two Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: A valiant effort, but lacking the subtlety of a true JK piece.

author: F. H Meredith
title: The makings of a good story, poorly handled.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
Ugh. There's the root of a good story here, too bad it was handled in such an inconsistent manner. Flashes of brilliance, depths of....well...not.

This is titled as a "rehearsal script." I'm interested to see how much of it survived the workshop and previews and made it into the final production -- including all of the wild staging challenges and multitudinous scene changes. This reads like a screen play incompetently posing as a stage play. And the characterizations of the now adult characters -- not a challenge I'd want to face -- is disappointing, to say the least.

Bottom line: this could have been a terrific novel, then movie if written by JKR. I can only hope they were able to fix the stage play. (Now I'll look for reviews of that.)

author: Brian Shockley

content: You can tell this book wasn't written exclusively by J. K. Rowling as the rest of them were. Seemed like a fan fiction novel I got halfway through and called it quits I was very disappointed and I love the the others and even the movies.  I will definitely see the play when it comes the town though.

author: Brenda Borgman
title: Not worth the money
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: I was so excited and am so disappointed with this book/script or whatever it is.  I knew it was a script when I bought it but thought it would contain a better story and plot.  This is just rubbish and lacks the fantastic adventure the other books had.  Not worth the money especially if you are not used to reading a script vs. a book.

author: bergie3000
title: Not the worst ever.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2016
content: The writing is often laughably amateurish. The story is ok.

author: Amazon Customer
title: I so wanted to like this...
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2017
content: First of all, I can't believe J.K. Rowling wrote this.  The change in character in Harry almost caused me to stop reading.  And secondly, I can't believe it was intended to be a play.  Most playwrights want their shows to be produced.  I've been a member of a theatre company for 46 years as both actor and director.  The special effects required to produce this play would make it a technical nightmare and beyond the scope of most theatre companies I know., not to mention the length!  I gave it two stars because I enjoyed the relationship of Albus and Scorpius, but was severely disappointed.

author: YARNOVERMOM
title: Short of being okay.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2016
content:
Being a huge fan of the 'Harry Potter" series I was totally and completely overwhelmed with excitement when I heard this one was coming out.  Even though it was initially advertised as another book addition of the series only 20 years later I soon found out it was a play.  I do believe there will be and have already been several fans who felt much disappointment when they found out it was actually a play.  At first I also was skeptical.  However, I am a die-hard fan like my son so he bought this one for me as a gift and I couldn't wait to open it to the adventure it would take me on.  I admit it was a bit of a setback to find it was in fact a play, however mild it was.  With that said I want to assure other die-hard fans who have yet to get the book since finding out it is a play that you will not have any trouble reading it.  Here's why:  The human mind after learning to read in it's youth stops reading a word completely and only mentally acknowledges the first and last letters of the word.  It is the same with reading all of the "he said." and 'she said." because our minds already are reading along in the conversation and know who 'he' is and 'she' is so it basically skips over that and goes on to thoughts of the characters, their surroundings and what is going on in the environment they are in.  So, a play just has more dialogue between the characters than a book does and mildly throws in the environment and actions of the character and those in that particular moment.  Granted there is less to read and if you are not actually watching the play you have to use some, however little, of your imagination to get the gist of what is going on.  I assure you you will be able to read it and follow.

J. K. Rowling does not disappoint for part in this addition to the series.  For Part though.  I still had a hard time figuring out exactly who the 'Cursed Child' was, even still I'm not sure I have it right.  What I'm saying is it was never made clear.  All the previous 'Harry Potter' books in the series gave a problem to solve of which the three main characters would put their heads together and come up with a solution to defeat the villain, Voldemort.  In this play you will find you feel you are just going back and forth to the same scenes over and over with the only difference being they are in different times of their parents past.  There is a time-turner that lets them go back in time to change things for a different outcome.  No biggy right.  Not exactly.  It gets monotonous, repetitive and quite frankly boring.  Honestly, I am hoping that J. K. Rowling DID NOT write the majority of this play and maybe just put her name on it (even that's not good).  Of all the books she has written on her own, to put her name on this play just ruins her reputation as a great writer.  The premise of the story was good for sure, I just don't think there was much thought put into the actual story.  Harry Potter really only plays an itty bitty part in the whole book.  The only reasoning I can think of to even mention him is to sell more books since not many fans would go out and buy 'The Cursed Child" without 'Harry Potter' being put on the title somewhere.

Quite honestly, I am disappointed and sort of feel cheated.  Not because it is a play but because all the other books in the series were so great while this one falls short of being just okay.

So lastly, if you are a die hard fan like myself and thinking you are going to read this fantastic 'Harry Potter' book, I would say wait till you can buy it used or just save your money and check out at the library.

author: Ali Thomas
title: I liked this book more than I had anticipated I would
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2016
content: As someone who isn't a huge Harry Potter fanatic, I liked this book more than I had anticipated I would. I read all of the books as a kid so I felt as though I needed to read this one too. The fact that it was written as a play did make it a little difficult to get past, but once I did I liked it more. It was different and it's not the Harry Potter that most people were probably expecting. Some things that I had expected to be in the book were not there and that was slightly disappointing. Overall, it was an okay book, but read it for yourself to find out.

I feel like the writers took the characters and bulldozed away their characterization and completely disregarded it in some cases.

content: This book was disappointing. I realize it is a play and the style is very different, but it was difficult to want to finish, not very interesting.

author: C. Mannino
title: Disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content:
This play, hailed as the supposed 8th Potter story falls flat in every way:

60% spectacle
30% nostalgia
10% substance

I enjoy Potter and have been in theatre for almost my entire life. As both a Potter fan and a theatre professional, I was disappointed. The idea of putting a Potter story on stage is brilliant, and I admit I haven't seen the stage production. I'm aware there are already thousands of reviews and it's one of the bestselling books of the year, but still wanted to give my thoughts.

60% Spectacle. - Spectacle can be a wonderful thing in stage shows. When done correctly, a bit of stage magic can push a production to a new level and leave the audience amazed. An example would be Elphaba's flight at the end of Act One in "Wicked." The effect isn't particularly challenging, but the spectacle is completely necessary. The character embraces the role she's been assigned by others, and takes to the air singing an iconic song. The moment advances both character and plot, and fits seamlessly into the show. In contrast, the majority of this play is nothing BUT spectacle, and spectacle for spectacle's sake. I'm sure these endless effects look dazzling on the stage, but they do NOT make for good theatre. Scene after scene flies by, most of them two minutes long or shorter, giving absolutely no character or plot advancement- but showing special effects for the audience to smile at. The feeling is more like going to a theme park than living through a well-constructed play. When a show is nothing but spectacle you end up with something like Spiderman: Turn off the Dark, and the only reason this show isn't bombing is the following...

30% Nostalgia - this is the reason the show sold out, and the reason it's such a popular book. I'll admit, I had it too, while reading. All the favorite characters are there, with the exception of Dobby. Even dead characters like Snape and Dumbledore make an appearance. In addition there are scenes from the books played out in this play- such as when Hagrid brings Harry the cake (a dream sequence). The play's crammed with nostalgic moments, and there's nothing wrong with that, except Cursed Child never moves past the nostalgia phase.

10% Substance- there's very little story here, and the story itself is extremely weak. It's a time-travel story, focused on the effects of what happens if some events in the stories, particularly book four, are changed. Each of the seven novels brings us deeper into a new aspect of the Wizarding World- new places, new ideas, new characters. That's what I looked forward to the most. There are almost NO new ideas in this story at all. Showing the world as if Voldemort had won was interesting for moment, but it didn't make up for the lack of substance in this story. The back and forth time-jumping was weak, the characters of Harry and Draco's sons not particularly innovative, and the entire story just felt flat. The "substance" of Cursed Child honestly felt more like a fanfic homage to the series. At the same time, both the spectacle and nostalgia remain paramount- let's watch Draco and Harry fight with wands and fly across the stage, let's see dementors suck souls- and look here's Bane- no reason for him to be here, but isn't it great to see him... you get the idea.

Overall, I'm not rushing to see this play onstage, and found this entire story lackluster. I hope the movies coming out are better, but honestly my expectations are low.

author: Suzanne
title: Disappointed
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: Nope. Just nope. This play was nothing more than crafty pandering to loyal Harry Potter fans in order to make a buck. I'm ashamed I fell for it. I feel stupid and disappointed. Maybe I have myself to blame for thinking this was something it wasn't. Oh well. Two stars. My heart won't let me give anything associated with HP one star. I think it is time to officially leave Harry Potter to live out his days in peace. I'm just going to pretend I never read this.

author: Cynthia Boss
title: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child by J.K. Rowling

I think the cursed child  is barely worth the read. I have come to expect excellence in a J.K Rowling book and this book was so much less than her first book. All her other books built on the book before with darker and deeper characters. This seemed more like a first draft.

content: I tried so hard to enjoy this but it just didn't capture the magic of Harry Potter. I wish I'd never read this and let the Deathly Hallows end the story

author: Amazon Customer
title: Wasn't accurate with JK's HP universe (spoiler alerts)
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: Let me just start by saying I am a HUGE Potterhead. I love the original 7 books and I love all 8 of the movies. I also knew, prior to preordering, that this was in fact a screenplay - that wasn't an issue for me. My issue with Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is that I felt like it wasn't accurate with the JK Rowling's HP universe & characters. First off, (spoiler alert!) Hermione Granger is one of the CLEVEREST witches in the entire series. I felt that it is HIGHLY unlikely that she would've hid a time turner in a book shelf??? with a riddle easy enough for a teenager to figure out??? Second, I really don't understand how Cedric Diggory, who was a Hufflepuff - loyal and kind, would end up to be a Death Eater just because he was humiliated? Honestly that makes no sense. I also don't see why Amos Diggory didn't move on? It had been 20+ years since his son died. Honestly I could go on, but I will leave it at that.

author: Fojo131
title: Two Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2016
content: love all things Harry purchased as a gift but this was a hard read ,

author: C. Burns
title: I wished it was a novel and not a play

author: Cybrarian

content: It was Ok. I really wanted another Herry Potter book, so this was a reasonable substitute, just not as captivating as the original series. Don`t get why the author isn't just sticking with the successful series.e

author: Battaglia Family
title: Two Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2016
content: It was okay but I would have preferred narrative instead of play form.

author: MC
title: Jack Thorne and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Play
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2016
content:
First of all, I wasn't that excited about the Cursed Child to begin with. Of course I was anxious to have another Harry Potter story, but I wasn't swooning over the idea like Mrs. Weasley lost her mind over Gilderoy Lockheart. I am one of those Potter fans who pretend the Epilogue in Deathly Hallows doesn't exist. I DESPISE Ginny (she is worse than Umbridge in my book) so I like to pretend Harry's life with her never actually happened. Hence the reason why I was excited to be back in the Harry Potter world, but I knew I wouldn't end up loving this story about Harry and Ginny.

Going into reading this book, I knew I probably wouldn't be thrilled with the plot, so I tried not to take that into consideration very much in my critique. Different strokes for different folks, you know? Just because I don't like the plot of a book doesn't mean it's a bad book.

Well...except in this case...

First of all, the plot was about a million times worse than I ever imagined. So ridiculous. But even disregarding the general plot, this book was awful. Really, truly, and very unfortunately, awful. I'm sure you have heard the same things over and over again, but there were so many things wrong with this book. The characters were NOTHING like they were in the rest of the Harry Potter series. Yes, people change as they age, but not like that. I am trying to keep this discussion spoiler free, but if you have read Cursed Child, I'm sure you can think of multiple examples. There were also huge changes to the world and magic system that J.K. Rowling created. And honestly, it felt like these changes were made just because it made the plot fall into place easier. What a cop out for the sake of convenience.

I could talk more about all the little intricacies of this script that bugged the hell out of me, but the internet is swarming with these types of discussions and I don't want to get myself all worked up over it. Let's talk instead about my biggest problem with this script. The writing was HORRIBLE. Yes, I understand that reading a script is different than reading a novel. But there are many plays that I adore and have read multiple times. This. Writing. Was. Awful. The stage directions were nonexistent, the plot was WAY too convenient, the characters were flat and dull and absolutely obnoxiously stupid, and I therefore spent about 90% of my time reading alternating between confused, bored, and angry.

Honestly, there is SO MUCH that is wrong with this work. But I truly don't want to talk about it anymore. Like so many people, Harry Potter means the world to me. It breaks my heart that this awful thing now exists and is supposed to be considered an "eighth story." I don't want to discuss my dislike of this book anymore because I want to forget as much as I can as quickly as possible. It has left a bad taste in my mouth and I don't want my Harry Potter love tainted by it. I'm honestly so confused as to how J.K. Rowling could sign off on this idea. After all that she has created, it seems so strange that she would let it be muddled by Jack Thorne and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Play.

author: Andy Demsky
title: Are we sure this isn't an elaborate artificial intelligence experiment?
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2016
content: Reading this book/script felt like I'd just read a story produced by a very powerful and skillfully programmed computer, the sort of super machine that had been fed all of the (real) Harry Potter books and had been outfitted with a software program that would help it take all the elements of those previous books and construct a story. If this book were the results of an experiment in artificial intelligence, it would be a smash success. But if not, it's a just joyless, uninspired shadow of all things that have come before it. Do yourself a favor -- skip this and re-read one of the actual HP novels.

author: Rachel
title: Missing the Magic
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
I, like may other reviewers, grew up on the Harry Potter books and they hold a special place in my heart. In the series, J.K. Rowling draws readers in with her descriptive imagery and character development. If you read the books before watching the movies, I'm sure you experienced that moment of "Wow! That character came to life on screen exactly as I imagined." This new expansion of the Harry Potter series completely lacks the magic of the original seven books; there is neither imagery nor character development. Albums Severus's problems seem like the trivial banalities teenagers often feel during their adolescent years. The original characters seem at odds with their book descriptions -- Harry is weak-minded, Ron a "hilarious" jokester, and Hermione's spells were unable to keep out a few teenagers?

The character I most enjoyed was that of Scorpius Malfoy, as it seems that the writers put most of their character development into his persona. Also, the idea of Hermione as the Minister of Magic was smart, but poorly executed and underdeveloped.

I agree with many others that this does not read like a storyline written by J.K. Rowling. J.K. Rowling's words brought magic into the homes of people all over the world. In this story the magic falls flat.

author: Christopher George Hartmann
title: Boring, predictable, simple, fan-pandering nonsense. Enjoy!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2016
content:
A blind person with no fingers could read this book in about 20 minutes. So if you think about it - this is probably the most expensive piece of writing ever created proportional to the amount of time it takes to read it.

So maybe you want to own a piece of literary history in the form of an over simplistic adaption novel?

Or maybe your the kind of guy who likes to read an entire book mid-step?

Either way - dont be a melon and buy this book. Just have a 1 year old explain it to you.

author: Kindle Customer
title: It had so much potential but fell short.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content: This is longest it ever took me to read a Harry Potter book. I hated the format.  A script is meant to be performed not read. There was none of the cleverness of the original books. The story was going but it never accomplished what it could have.

author: Liza
title: I'm going to forget I read it!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: While I had no problem with it written in play form, this did not live up to the Harry Potter series. The characters were nothing like the friends we loved and cheered on in the original books. It read like bad fan fiction. I did enjoy Scorpius. I'm just going to stick with the epilogue from Deathly Hallows and pretend Cursed Child was a bad dream.

author: Chris P
title: Accio Dittany
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
To heal my broken heart.

So this is what I'll say to you

20 minutes in as my breath is gasping (but not in a good gaspy kind of way, in a horrific I'm fighting the Unforgivable Curse kind of way) and I'm moaning nooooooooooo nooooooooooo please noooooo and my husband comes running to see what's the matter and I blubber "But it violates Potter Canon Law!!!  How could she do that?  WHY would she do that?"

Are you the type of person who understands what I mean?  Or are you the type of person like my husband who says "Who Cares?  Is it funny?"  If you are him, buy and enjoy.  Whatevs.

For the rest of us, this is not what we expect from J.K. Rowling.  Ever.  Whether she sanctioned it, wrote it, approved it, or simply just wanted us to pay for it.  It's a little like Alternate Reality Mean Hermione.  This is not the J.K. Rowling material that we know, love, quote to our children as life lessons and inspires us to decorate our bathrooms in "Ravenclaw" and I'm not sure I personally can adapt.

2 Stars because it is probably a really nice theatrical production inspired by the Harry Potter world.  But as a sanctioned "The 8th Story" it doesn't even deserve one of them.  T for Troll.

Keep precious Scorpius, send the rest back

author: Homer Prker
title: disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content: This book sorely disappoints.  Not one but all the characters did not follow the previous books.  Everyone behaved and acted out of character

author: Nicole

content: I'm a huge Harry Potter fan, and this did not live up to expectations. You can definitely tell that JK Rowling didn't write this and I feel the quality of the writing doesn't live up to the author's standards. Different tone, character development, even inconsistencies with previous works.  I understand that this was a play script, and not a true novel.  It was wonderful to return to the magical world again, but this just didn't fit in with the Harry Potter series.

author: joanne c
title: Not what I thought it would be. For some ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content: Not what I thought it would be. For some reason I thought it was going to be Rowling's novel, not some other guy's screen play. I should have paid attention more I guess.

author: Colin
title: Not what I hoped

content: Not a fan. It does not have the same feel as any of the other books. I don't think JK Rowling was involved at all in the writing. If she was then I'm pretty disappointed. This felt forced and unnatural and the characters didn't feel like the same characters we've all come to know and love

author: Katie Smith
title: ... fan of the Harry Potter series I was very disappointed to read this book
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2016
content: After being a big fan of the Harry Potter series I was very disappointed to read this book. I had a hard time getting into the style. I wish she had just written this book in a normal fashion.

I have absolutely no idea, but I will join the library's wait list for the next book. I'm not spending any more on an author who would let this drivel be published for an easy pay check.

author: gillian
title: Disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2016
content:
I was really looking forward to reading this book.  Like the other Harry Potter books always have been, I was hoping this would be a page turner for me.

It wasn't.  I thought it was repetitive, piecemeal and unconvincing.  I had a bit of a job finishing it.

Disappointing.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Just okay, but awful at the same time.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2016
content: No bad, but still quite disappointing. The voice of the characters is nothing like in the books. It seems apparent to me that Rowling had part in the formation of the story, but little to do with the actual writing. Overall, this did not have the sureal and rather magical Harry Potter feel. Regardless of the apparently tragedy this book is, I would still like to see the play at some point. Hopefully I could find it more entertaining than this book.

author: Reliable???
title: I'm mentally filing this story under fanfiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
I LOVE Harry Potter.  This series helped me through my roughest moments growing up, and I reread them constantly while awaiting the next volume.  So, I'm going to be the first person to say that I had HIGH expectations for this volume.

No spoiler spoilers, but I will be talking vaguely about the plot and characters.

I have decided to mentally file this story under interesting, but not believable fan fiction.  I just didn't believe the characters: Ron was too stupid, Draco was too mellow, Hermione and Ginny (and McGonagall in one memorable instance) were not assertive or sassy enough, and Harry and Hermione (and the character with whom Albus and Scorpius are obsessed) made some decisions that I just don't believe they would have ever made.  Some skilled actors MIGHT be able to pull this off, but it really did not read in the script.  Without that core of believable characters, the story fell apart for me.

Plot elements feel rather contrived as well--the villain (who was disappointingly obvious), the time travel.  In Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, time travel was handled brilliantly because both timelines worked simultaneously and fit perfectly.  While I like the idea of exploring the effects of one person's decisions, and some of the effects were definitely interesting to read about, this angle has been done and this version of time travel tarnishes the magic of Azkaban for me.

Also, Rowling's strength is description, so I'm not sure a script is the best media for her to use to tell a story.  I'm now a bit worried about Fantastic Beasts.

There were elements of the plays that I liked.  Scorpius is ADORABLE, and Albus and Scorpius' friendship is fun to read about.  They will be staying in my head cannon even if most of this play is not.  I also really liked the idea of Harry's fame being difficult for Albus to deal with and this causing tension between father and son.  In spite of the fact that I don't find all Harry's reactions believable, the relationship was interesting and often touching.  The part of the story that featured Scorpius on his own was fun to read and was probably the best part of the plays (for all my earlier complaints about time travel).  The scene with Hagrid towards the end made me cry.

All in all, I am disappointed, and I will, overall, be pretending this play is not sanctioned by Rowling.

author: Littlebookworm
title: What a shame
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
Oh what a disappointment! I'm battling with whether I should be disappointed or just accept this for what it is...but, no, I'm disappointed. Mostly I'm disappointed that JK Rowling allowed this to be published. I can imagine that this would be a good, fun and well produced, spin off play but publishing the script is unnecessary and feels like a sad attempt to cash-in.
JK is such a masterful author, she creates the most incredible, vivid alternate word and does this through wonderful prose and lengthy descriptions which the reader gets lost in. This play, in contrast, feels thin, rushed and flimsy. The characters Ron, Hermione and Harry feel like caricatures and, aside from Scorpius, the new characters we meet are underdeveloped and two dimensional.
There are grammatical errors throughout - I know it's a play but this is still unacceptable!Without pulling this apart for the sake of it there were also a few parts of this story which didn't sit right or seem feasible (I'm sure they can be explained though).
- Why is it so easy for Albus and Scorpius to cast spells on Cedric at the Tri Wizard tournament? Wouldn't all of the opposite teams be doing this to help their representatives all of the way through?
- How is Delphi able to spend so long in Godric's Hollow when the time turner only allows 5 minutes?
 - I just hate the scene where Harry and Dumbledore had their heart to heart and tell each other they love one another.

This shouldn't have been published; rather just left as a spin off play for people to enjoy and take for what it is.

i really thought i would love this book,but even when i started  the book it just did not feel like harry potter.when you open a harry potter book(audio or print)you get a feeling of excitement and happiness and this didn't have that feeling.I'm not saying that i blame J.k. Rowling for the book,if i had written all those kick-ass books i would want to write another one too,but somehow she(and those OTHER people)just didn't put the feeling into it.I'm guessing that the people who wrote it were doing it because they were bored and because lots of people wanted another book.I do not think this book is very good.it made me sad how they make harry potter when he grew up.he's so tactless and he completely forgot what it was like to be a kid.does he seriously think that Albus potter the kid of the coolest(next to Dumbledore of course)wizard in the wizarding world would stay away from his friend,adventure and fun? it's just so terrible to think that harry potter ended up just like Peter Pan in Hook.i thought it was kind of wierd has a kid and also Ginny's spark isn't there anymore.it just LEFT.
all in all i have to say that this just was not was i was hopeing
for.

author: Winsome
title: Wasted effort...don't bother.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2016
content: Such a disappointment!  First, and my own fault for not reading the fine print, it's not a novel; it's a manuscript for a play.  Think double spaced lines, scene changes every couple of pages which requrie chapter headings limiting print to about 1/2 page.  The book is slightly over 300 pages but the story is probably only a little over 100 altogether.  Virtually no descriptions...unless you count stage directives like 'Harry looks confused', sort of thing.  Richness of words, gone.  Depth of emotion, gone.  It's either conversation or brief stage directions.  Plot is Rowling-esque but contrived to constantly push the relationship pressure between father and son.  Everything else is economy--superficial, shallow.  Not worth the time or the money.

author: Corey
title: Don't Make This Your First Impression of Harry Potter!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2016
content:
I have a few things I really didn't like about this script and I will try not to spoil anything for those who have not yet read it.

My biggest negative after reading this as a Harry Potter fan was that the dialogue of the returning Harry Potter characters (Harry, Hermoine, Ron, etc.) felt very unnatural to the characters from the original series. I understand that Harry is now in his late 30s, early 40s in this play but there were times when I was reading his lines, and other returning characters' lines, where it just felt like that isn't something that character would say. There was also some dialogue that was really "cheesy" and felt like the writer was trying to force a laugh which made the line seem unnatural.

It is also missing the descriptive quality that made the original series so good, I understand it's a play and that quality would be lacking a bit but it was almost entirely absent in the scene descriptions.

The story line was pretty predictable (even the "twist" at the end was predictable) and was used much more effectively in other movies that had used it before.

I hope this review helps and I didn't spoil anything. I think any Harry Potter fan will check this out regardless of the reviews, as I did. But, if you're new to the Harry Potter series please read the original series and don't make this your first impression of Harry Potter.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Harry Potter and the Unnecessary Sequel
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
Harry Potter and the Diminishing Royalty Check took beloved characters a decade in the making and turned them into hollow mockeries of the people we had grown to love. From Harry's complete 180 from loving to overbearing father modes to Volde*cough*'s (thankfully) unseen sexy times, almost no character managed to avoid a drastic personality change.
Fans expecting a novelization of the play are in for disappointment, as this 'book' is simply a cut and paste of the script complete with stage directions, sudden jumps in scenery, and intermission cues.For an infinitely better play about magic in Britain, try 'A Midsummer Night's Dream'. But, for those whose very life depends on having every piece of Harry Potter merchandise, it won't hurt you to own this...at least for a little while.

author: Amber Boyer
title: I love Harry Potter and the world that Rowling has made
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
I am sorry to say that I feel giving 2 stars might be too generous.  I love Harry Potter and the world that Rowling has made.  I have been an overly obsessed fan since I was 12 yrs old and got the first book for Christmas.  That was 18 years ago and Harry, the Weasley's, Hermione, Luna, and so many more characters have been my best friends ever since.

I knew it was a play, and have no problems over looking the lack of narrative and reading the lines of my favorite people.  Unfortunately they weren't there.  This is less than a shell of the Harry Potter I know and love.  I feel that this was a failed attempt to move along a story that would have been best left in the epilogue of Deathly Hallows. I was fine with knowing that Harry and friend were okay, and the wizarding world was a better place because of the sacrifices of the characters we loved. In my opinion this play makes a mockery of the seven books and the story that Rowling told she should have never allowed these play writers to even imagine different possibilities for the story that she wrote. I don't know what else to say without spoiling the plot, bottom line this was a complete disappointment!

author: Read more books
title: Could have been better, could have been worse
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content: I didn’t know what I was suspecting going into this, but this play wasn’t that good. Now I understand this was a play and was not going to be a novel, but it’s not the writing format I have a problem with as much as the story. It just left more questions than it attempt to answer, and the character didn’t seem to have the same personality as in the earlier books. The characters are older, but they don’t even seem the same. I don’t know what more to say it wasn’t an absolute horrible read, but it wasn’t that good either. Sometimes the worst thing about a story is that people (and sometimes the author) will not let it end when it needs to end.

author: Swathi Guruduth
title: Okay!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2016
content:
All in all it is a good read if you want to know what happens 19 years later but that's just about it. Don't expect this book to take you into the world of magic and that of Hogwarts.

What I liked:
1. The story after 19 years.
2. It is in the form of a play.
3. That Albus and Scorpius are best buds.

What I did not like:
1. They have seriously messed up the concept of the time-turner.
2. The story is predictable.
3. It seemed more like watching (reading) one of the Harry Potter movies (I didn't like it as much as the original books).

author: Niki
title: Kinda like eating unseasoned chicken; edible but blah.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
I feel like I need to start by declaring my love of all things Harry Potter and that it pains me to say anything even slightly negative about the world and characters J.K. Rowling masterfully created but….

This book left me feeling flat. It was kinda like eating unseasoned chicken; edible but blah. Seeing as it’s a script as opposed to an actual novel, l was prepared for it to be lacking J.K.’s masterful descriptive language but I was still expecting a well-developed plot and characters that stayed true to their origins. (One tiny non-spoilery example is Cedric becoming a Deatheater because he was embarrassed. C’mon, really? I don’t think so.) I don’t think anyone else has the ability to write these characters and I have a feeling that any contribution Rowling made to this book were minuscule.

That being said, I still think diehard HP fans should read Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. Just make sure that before you crack the book (or swipe your Kindle) lower your expectations and then just for good measure, lower them again 🙁

author: K. Droddy
title: This book is not HP canon to me...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
So, I just finished reading Cursed Child and...I'm incredibly disappointed. I knew full well that this was merely a script and not a full-blown story. I'm totally fine with that..except for the fact that it's terrible.

*possible spoilers*

The initial excitement of holding a new HP book wore off incredibly quickly. The characters in CC have almost no semblance whatsoever to their true HP counterparts. They are flat and dull in so many ways.

And what's with the relationship between Scorpius and Albus? I fully expected this to turn into a full-blown romantic relationship because they reiterate their feelings for one another over...and over...and over...But it doesn't really add anything to the plot when they do!

Speaking of plot...this one is terrible! Time travel, angsty teenage drama, more time travel, random daughter of Voldemort, more time travel...There are more holes in this plot than a cheese grater!

Ugh..I have read the original HP series through many times, and will continue to do so. But this book will never be reread. I will likely give it away or give it to Goodwill as soon as my wife finishes reading it..Disappointing.

Two stars because I can't 'hate' anything HP, but this is cutting it incredibly close.

date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016

I will mention that apart from ridiculous plot and implausible characterizations, the play shows a kind of ponderousness that is mostly absent from the novels. Time and again the characters give long and trite lectures on their motivations or on the value of some ideal. Dumbledore in particular evinces none of the with and deftness he did in the books when he was being pedagogical.

date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2016

Okay. Harry Potter is the legendary series I will NEVER EVER regret reading; however this "Cursed Child" I have some doubts on. Ron gets drunk at his own wedding?! Cedric turns evil because he didn't win a competition?! Hermione, sweet, sweet Hermione...Has a bully for a daughter?! As if she wouldn't instill her own values in Rose! I hate this. And where's Teddy? Hugo? The only reason I gave it two stars is because a) It's still distinctly related to HP, b) Scorbus <3

author: kimmiegail
title: So disappointed. I preordered the book and couldn't wait to ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: So disappointed.  I preordered the book and couldn't wait to get it, but I had no idea it was written in screenplay format.  It is extremely difficult to read.  I wonder if they make an audiobook will it be easier to listen to?  I love HP and have all of the movies, books, and audiobooks as well as visiting Universal Studios Orlando three times just to go to the HP theme parks.

author: Amazon Customer
title: lackluster
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content:
I really wanted to like this story........ Like most people that probably bought this book, I grew up on the Harry Potter stories.  When I first heard a continuation to the series was coming out, I was excited.  I thought we would finally get the ending that the Harry Potter series deserved; I honestly did not think anything could be worse than the rushed epilogue of "The Deathly Hollows"....I was wrong.
 I tried to be objective going into this book.  Honestly, while I have reread all the books multiple times and have  seen all the movies, I would not consider myself one of the many rabid  Harry Potter fans.  I recognized this was an adaptation to the story, so I was not looking for continuation errors.  It did not bother me that details in the books were overlooked and missing in "The Cursed Child".  It did not bother me that they made the Trolley Witch bonkers and Harry Potter's kid obnoxious.  What bothered me is they murdered the characters that made the Harry Potter stories great. It's a sad day when Draco Malfoy is the only decent original character in the story.
 Harry, Ginny, Ron, and Hermione where nothing like the characters in the original books. The heart of the original stories failed to be transmitted into "The Cursed Child".  There was nothing about any of the characters that made you love them, root for them, or even wish them dead.  The dialog was forced and one-dimensional. While the Harry Potter series were technically children/young adult novels, this story, above all the others, felt like it was truly geared towards young children. It was cheesy line after cheesy line, cliché after cliché.  By the end, I was even okay with the bad guys  winning - at least then, the story may have some oomph behind it.  But alas, the book managed to go all the way to the end without any redeeming characteristics.  The only reason I did not give this a one-star is it has the potential for actors to break the one-dimensionality of this script in a live production.  As written, this should have just been a free read online.  But, hey, anything for a more $$$, right?

author: DrCarol
title: Two Stars

content: Too many plot holes and inconsistent characterizations.

content:
I'm a huge Potter fan. I've been reading the books ever since they came out at least once a year. A couple of things to be noted.. the screenplay kind of writing makes it very dull and somehow hard to follow. I don't think JK Rowling actually wrote a single line. why do I say that? only because I can't see her style, it lacks the magical touch and humor that made the characters so loveable and unique..
Without the magical touch, they are just a bunch of teenagers with magical powers... yawn, that's the kind of boring stuff you can watch all day on U.S. TV...  boring boring boring...

author: ShowThisBookSomeLove
title: So much of the storyline just felt like a cop-out in that they took whole scenes from ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2016
content:
I had a really hard time getting anywhere with this book. In fact, to be honest, I didn’t hardly read it at all. So much of the storyline just felt like a cop-out in that they took whole scenes from J.K. Rowling’s books and reorganized them for the play. I didn’t like reading this in script format, it just didn’t fit the imagery behind Rowling’s Harry Potter. I’m curious about the live performance, but otherwise this story is dead to me. Honestly I didn’t even want to read it, but a friend had a copy so I borrowed it to see if it was any good. I can’t say that I’m disappointed because my expectations were already really low, but I will say that there wasn’t much I found enjoyable about Harry Potter and the Cursed Child.

That’s all I want to say about this book – a short review is fitting for a book that I couldn’t even get through.

author: HannahofIN
title: This script made me believe in buying paper books again...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content:
Since the advent of Kindle, I've rarely bought paper books any more. Digital books are easier to store and a lot of time they're cheaper too.
When Harry Potter and the Cursed Child came out, I thought about getting a hard copy...I love the Harry Potter series and what better way to celebrate the new story than to buy a book that I can display on my shelf? But old habits die hard and I got the ebook instead.
Halfway through the Cursed Child, I became terrified that Rowling would release a new edition of the Deathly Hallows (my favorite in the series and one of my all-time favorite books ever). Being a Star Wars fan as well as a Harry Potter fan, I'm well aware of the tendency to change the older, more beloved stories to fit the "new stuff" instead of taking care to make sure the new stuff doesn't contradict the real story--and I don't want my Deathly Hallows changed, thank you very much. It's Harry and not Ginny who tells Albus that "He likes a laugh, your brother". I know kindle periodically sends out updates to books and what if one day I accidentally hit a button and my Deathly Hallows gets "updated"? What if Harry isn't a good father in my epilogue anymore?
Having worked myself up into a complete panic, I hurried to Amazon and bought myself a paper copy of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows. There. Now the story will always end like it's supposed to: Harry's a great dad and his scar doesn't hurt. You'll have to break into my house and vandalize my beloved book before that changes.

In the interest of fairness, I will say that I thoroughly enjoyed the character of Scorpious Malfoy and had the play followed his schooldays' adventures with Albus Potter, I would have willingly purchased a paper copy of that story...instead of whatever it was the play actually was. It wasn't just that I didn't like how much it changed things and characters, the script just really didn't hold my attention. I kept drifting off while reading (and I used to read Shakespeare's play scripts as a child, so it wasn't the format that bored me). It just...wasn't good and wasn't Harry Potter.

author: Monica  Richey, .

author: NarrowGate
title: A Disappointing Story/"Greatest Hits" That Plays It Safe
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2016
content: SPOILERS! As a huge Harry Potter fan, I was very much looking forward to "Book 8" to see what new adventure would add to the rich mythology of the Wizarding World. Unfortunately there is no new ground plowed and most of the plot elements are just a rehash of the previous books. Here is the plot summary - Albus and Scorpius use a time turner (a la Azkaban) to go back in time to "fix" the past (save Cedric Diggory). They end up messing up the present which becomes worse and so they go back in time to undo what they did and so the present ends up like it was at the beginning of the story. In the mean time, Voldemort's daughter goes back in time to "save" him from trying to kill baby Harry, so the main characters have to go back in time to stop Voldemort's daughter, which also ends up keeping the present time as is. That's basically it. (How Voldemort and Bellatrix have a baby before the Battle of Hogwarts is a mystery). This story does very  little to expand Harry's story or the Wizarding World. (For much of the book, Harry's story is how his fathering skills have been lacking.) Most of our favorite characters are brought back - Harry, Hermione, Ron, Ginny, Draco, McGonagall, Snape, Dumbledore, Hagrid, Umbridge, etc. The children visit the three events of the Triwizard Tournament from Goblet of Fire. Time turners play a major role - nothing new there either. The children use polyjuice potion to plan a heist at the Ministry of Magic (a la Deathly Hallows) to steal the time turner from Hermione's office. I could go on, but in short, none of this is inventive. If Rowling really wrote this story, then there was very little effort involved since this turns out to be more of a "best of hits" from the seven books. One of the greatest stories every written simply deserves far more than this. Rowling displayed extraordinary world building in the past, but that is absent here. I have no doubt that the London play is an "astonishing" feat, but the story itself falls woefully short of the first seven Harry Potter books.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Eh
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Major disappointment in the annoying play format as well as the quality of the story compared to books 1-7 of the Harry Potter series.

author: PWDecker
title: A Disappointment
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2017
content:
I was disappointed. There was so much potential. This just comes off as fan fiction. I understand that this is the script for a play, but the things that I didn't like are basic story elements. Those elements might be covered up by glitz and explosions when you see it on stage, but they were my biggest grievance.

I do not like how time travel is used in this book. Time travel was done so well in the Harry Potter series. The rules introduced here seem so arbitrary and don't make sense. It seems more like a way to show scenes and characters that the audience will enjoy.

The tacked on romance at the end is so stupid. The Harry Potter series gets flack for the relationships set up late in the series, but Rowling did an excellent job of writing friendship. This book is the opposite. It writes a budding romantic relationship so well, but it calls it just a friendship in the end.

There are good things this book did. Slytherin was shown in a different light. Complexities of adulthood and the difficulties of parenthood were shown well.

I wanted so much from this book so maybe I am being unfair in my critique, but I give this book a 2/5. I absolutely want to see this play. I may even read this book again, but I don't think it is good. The rating is also comparing it to the standard I have for all things Harry Potter.

author: StockShowMom
title: mediocre fan fic.  Not impressed at all.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2016
content: I was excited to get this.  It came in just a couple of days.  Great service, Amazon.  I waited til the weekend so I could settle in and get lost in another JKR work.  I expected it to be a different sort of read since it's a script but I've read lots of scripts and never had any problem enjoying the story.  I read the entire book in two sittings; kept waiting to be drawn in...the next page....ok the next chapter.  I don't know how much of this was actually written by JKR and how much was written by the two co-authors, but this reads like a mediocre fan fic.  I've never been disappointed in anything with Jo Rowling's name on it, until now.  There were a couple of instances where details were completely wrong, as though the author perhaps didn't read the HP books closely enough to catch them.  The best I can say is that I am glad I have it so I'm not missing a piece of the HP collection.  Unlike the 7 HP books, however, I won't need a second copy of this one to keep in good shape as I wear out the first with rereadings.  I won't bother to reread this.  I also won't waste my time going to see it on stage next time I go to London.
